newsitem.title: USA: Tech shares jump on Cisco profit, Prop 211 defeat.
newsitem.headline: Tech shares jump on Cisco profit, Prop 211 defeat.

text.p: Shares of high-tech companies surged Wednesday after news of strong earnings from Cisco Systems Inc and the defeat of a California measure that could have threatened technology profits.

After the market closed yesterday, Cisco, the world's biggest maker of computer networking equipment and a bellwhether technology stock, said its first-quarter earnings jumped 77 percent, better than Wall Street expected.

California voters also rejected a ballot initiative that would have made it easier for investors to sue companies for stock drops. Technology companies with volatile stocks have been a favorite target of expensive class-action lawsuits.

"We defeated the jackals of Proposition 211, the carrion feeders who would take away our profits," said James Cramer, principal of money management firm Cramer Partners in New York, which owns $225 million of stocks. In addition, recent worries about weak personal computer sales are "premature," he said.
In early afternoon trading, Cisco shares, the most active in U.S. markets, were up 1/8 at 61-7/8. The stock had risen about seven percent in the past week in anticipation of strong earnings.
Compaq Computer Corp, the world's biggest PC maker, was up 1 1/2 at 71 7/8. And Intel Corp, the world's biggest maker of computer chips, rose 2-1/8 to 116-1/8.
The technology-laden Nasdaq market composite was up 10.63 at 1239.70.

"Cisco is notorious for saying they can't grow like this forever, yet they announced that their revenue grew 80 percent," said Kevin Baker, who manages $750 million of technology stocks for John Hancock Funds.
Baker also said President Bill Clinton's re-election reflects consumers' view that the economy was good.
"For the big guys like Compaq and Intel, things will continue to be strong," Baker said.
Other technology shares posting big gains included database software developer Oracle Corp, up 1-1/8 at 45 1/4; Microsoft Corp, up 1 at 142-1/2; and Texas Instrument Inc, up 3-1/4 at 52-1/4.
Cramer said the gains were the start "of a big run to the end of the year."
